subject: Philosophy
title: Rights-Based Ethics
description: A short lesson to help you apply Rights-Based Ethics.

hook.text: You can't torture one person even if it would save a hundred. That's a rights-based claim.

buildup.text: John Locke argued that people have natural rights â€” life, liberty, and property â€” just by being human.

discovery.text: Rights act as moral shields. They protect individuals from being sacrificed for the greater good.

twist.text: But rights can conflict. Your right to free speech may clash with someone else's right to safety.

climax.text: Every modern constitution is built on rights-based ethics. The argument is about which rights matter most.

punchline.text: Rights are the walls that protect the individual.

quiz.question: What function do rights serve in ethics?
options: They protect individuals from being sacrificed for the group
